string-array.name: txtModel_Des
string-array.item: The catenoid is a minimal surface that arises as the shape of a soap film spanning two circular rings.

An ellipsoid is a three-dimensional geometric shape resembling a stretched sphere. It is defined by three perpendicular axes of different lengths, and it can be described as a surface obtained by rotating an ellipse about one of its axes.

A helicoid is a three-dimensional curved surface that resembles a spiral staircase. It can be formed by twisting a straight line around a central axis, resulting in a surface that spirals up or down along the length of the axis.

A hyperbolic paraboloid is a three-dimensional shape that resembles a saddle or a Pringles potato chip. It is defined by two sets of intersecting straight lines that form a series of hyperbolic curves, resulting in a surface with both concave and convex regions.

A hyperboloid is a three-dimensional shape that resembles two hyperbolas connected at their vertices. It can be formed by rotating a hyperbola around its axis, resulting in a surface with two distinct sheets and a central waist.

A Möbius strip is a two-dimensional surface with only one side and one edge. It is formed by taking a strip of paper, giving it a half-twist, and then joining the ends together. A Möbius strip has many interesting mathematical properties and is often used as a symbol of infinity or continuity.

A paraboloid is a three-dimensional shape that resembles a bowl or a satellite dish. It can be formed by rotating a parabola around its axis, resulting in a surface with a single, concave bowl-shaped region.

A torus is a three-dimensional shape that resembles a doughnut or a lifebuoy. It can be formed by rotating a circle around an axis that lies in the same plane as the circle, resulting in a surface with a hole in the middle and a circular cross-section.
